channel.title: Java Variables/Strings - Java from step 1? *Vote Now!* - Click for more info
channel.description:
Main Variables -
int = set of numeric numbers from -24billion to 24 billion String = set of alphabetic or symbols char = a single valued letter or symbol with single qoutation marks boolean = used to store the value of true or false byte = any number from the range of -128 to 127 short = it's smaller then the int but larger then the byte, stores numbers from -32,768 to 32,767 long = typically used to store numbers too big for the int to hold, stores numbers from -9.22 quintillion to 9.22 quintillion float = stands for floating-point variables, stores decimal point numbers. Final int = forgetten what it stands for lol... it's been a while...
Naming Variables - variables can be named with any alphabetic or numeric value, but can only be named with certain symbols, these are: (the underscore (_)) and (the dollar sign ($)). NOTE: Java is case sensative when it comes to variables.
Using special characters in Strings -
\' Single qoutation mark \" Double qoutation mark \n New line \\ Back slash \t Tab \r Carriage return \f Formfeed \b Backspace (i think that's all of them... :s ) You can use System.out.println() or System.out.print() .. but the second one is recommended if you're using a character with the String... if you just want a new line i recommend using println with \n char... for example: System.out.println("music by \nMichael Nyman") This will look like this:
Music By Michael Nyman
When you work with system.out.println() and work with strings in other ways, you can paste two strings together by using +, the same operator that is used to add numbers.
The + operator has a different meaning in relation with Strings... It can add two strings together or make one big strings out of two smaller ones... But i don't want to get too into detail about that just yet...
[center][u][b][font=arial]If you think i should make a squence of tutorials from the very very start of java programming then vote above, keep in mind, this will be for people who don't know anything at all about java. [/font][/b][/u][/center]
- NieX

item.title: Java Variables/Strings - Java from step 1? *Vote Now!* - Click for more info
item.dc:creator: @NieX NieX
item.description:
@NieX wrote:

Main Variables -

int = set of numeric numbers from -24billion to 24 billion
String = set of alphabetic or symbols
char = a single valued letter or symbol with single qoutation marks
boolean = used to store the value of true or false
byte = any number from the range of -128 to 127
short = it’s smaller then the int but larger then the byte, stores numbers from -32,768 to 32,767
long = typically used to store numbers too big for the int to hold, stores numbers from -9.22 quintillion to 9.22 quintillion
float = stands for floating-point variables, stores decimal point numbers.
Final int = forgetten what it stands for lol… it’s been a while…

Naming Variables -
variables can be named with any alphabetic or numeric value, but can
only be named with certain symbols, these are: (the underscore (_))
and (the dollar sign ($)).
NOTE: Java is case sensative when it comes to variables.

Using special characters in Strings -

’ Single qoutation mark
" Double qoutation mark
\n New line
\ Back slash
\t Tab
\r Carriage return
\f Formfeed
\b Backspace
(i think that’s all of them… :s )
You can use System.out.println() or System.out.print() … but the second
one is recommended if you’re using a character with the String…
if you just want a new line i recommend using println with \n char…
for example:
System.out.println(“music by \nMichael Nyman”)
This will look like this:

Music By
Michael Nyman

When you work with system.out.println() and work with strings in other
ways, you can paste two strings together by using +, the same operator
that is used to add numbers.

The + operator has a different meaning in relation with Strings…
It can add two strings together or make one big strings out of
two smaller ones… But i don’t want to get too into detail about that
just yet…

[center][font=arial]If you think i should make a squence of tutorials from the very very
start of java programming then vote above, keep in mind, this will be
for people who don’t know anything at all about java. [/font][/center]

  • NieX

Read full topic
